semantic_title: Underdosing Classification and Coding Requirements Including Noncompliance and Complication Codes
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > e. Adverse Effects, Poisoning, Underdosing and Toxic Effects > 5. The occurrence of drug toxicity > (c) Underdosing

content.full_text: Underdosing refers to taking less of a medication than is prescribed by a provider or a manufacturer's instruction. Discontinuing the use of a prescribed medication on the patient's own initiative (not directed by the patient's provider) is also classified as an underdosing. For underdosing, assign the code from categories T36-T50 (fifth or sixth character "6"). Documentation of a change in the patient's condition is not required in order to assign an underdosing code. Documentation that the patient is taking less of a medication than is prescribed or discontinued the prescribed medication is sufficient for code assignment. Codes for underdosing should never be assigned as principal or first-listed codes. If a patient has a relapse or exacerbation of the medical condition for which the drug is prescribed because of the reduction in dose, then the medical condition itself should be coded. Noncompliance (Z91.12-, Z91.13-, Z91.14- and Z91.A4-) or complication of care (Y63.6-Y63.9) codes are to be used with an underdosing code to indicate intent, if known. (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L86)
content.summary: Comprehensive guidelines for underdosing classification, coding requirements, sequencing rules, and use of additional codes for noncompliance or complications of care (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L86)
key_concepts: Underdosing definition and scope (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L81)
5th or 6th character "6" for underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
No condition change documentation required (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)
Never principal or first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)
Medical condition coding priority (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L84)
Noncompliance and complication codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Underdosing refers to taking less medication than prescribed or discontinuing prescribed medication on patient's own initiative (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L81)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing includes both taking reduced amounts of prescribed medication and patient-initiated discontinuation of prescribed medications without provider direction (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L81)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For underdosing, assign code from categories T36-T50 with 5th or 6th character "6" (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
detailed_rules.explanation: The character "6" in the 5th or 6th position specifically identifies underdosing as the type of drug-related problem (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Documentation of a change in patient's condition is not required to assign underdosing code (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: Unlike other drug-related codes, underdosing codes can be assigned based solely on documentation of taking less medication or discontinuing medication, without requiring evidence of clinical consequences (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Codes for underdosing should never be assigned as principal or first-listed codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing codes are always secondary codes and cannot be the primary reason for the encounter or admission (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If patient has relapse or exacerbation due to dose reduction, code the medical condition itself (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L84)
detailed_rules.explanation: When underdosing results in worsening of the condition being treated, the medical condition should be coded as the primary diagnosis, with underdosing as secondary (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L84)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use noncompliance (Z91.12-, Z91.13-, Z91.14-, Z91.A4-) or complication of care (Y63.6-Y63.9) codes with underdosing to indicate intent (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)
detailed_rules.explanation: Additional codes should be used alongside underdosing codes to specify whether the underdosing was due to patient noncompliance or complications of care, if this information is known (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify underdosing situation (less medication or discontinuation)
Step 2: Determine if medical condition worsened due to underdosing
Step 3: If condition worsened, code medical condition as primary
Step 4: Assign underdosing code with character "6" as secondary
Step 5: Determine if underdosing was due to noncompliance or care complications
Step 6: Add appropriate Z91 or Y63 codes if intent known

code_ranges.description: Categories for underdosing with 5th or 6th character "6" (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
code_ranges.requirement: Use character 6 for underdosing, never as principal diagnosis
usage_rules: 5th or 6th character "6" identifies underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
Never assign as principal or first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)

code_ranges.description: Noncompliance codes to use with underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L85)
code_ranges.requirement: Use to indicate noncompliance intent if known
usage_rules: Use with underdosing codes when noncompliance is the cause (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)
Indicates patient-initiated underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)

code_ranges.description: Complication of care codes for underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L85-L86)
code_ranges.requirement: Use to indicate care-related underdosing if known
usage_rules: Use when underdosing results from care complications (Evidence: pg no: 84, L85-L86)
Indicates system or provider-related underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L85-L86)

code_patterns.description: Complete underdosing coding pattern (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L86)
code_patterns.explanation: Medical condition first, underdosing secondary, intent code if known (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L86)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with diabetes stopped taking insulin on their own, resulting in hyperglycemia
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Type 2 diabetes with hyperglycemia due to patient discontinuing insulin without provider approval
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify medical condition (diabetes with hyperglycemia)
Step 3: Code diabetes with hyperglycemia as primary
Step 4: Code insulin underdosing with character 6 as secondary
Step 5: Add noncompliance code (Z91.120) for intent

correct_coding.sequencing: Medical condition first, underdosing secondary, noncompliance third
correct_coding.rationale: Medical condition takes priority when worsened by underdosing, underdosing never principal (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L86)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Underdosing codes never principal or first-listed

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient found to be taking half doses of prescribed medication during admission
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient reports taking only half the prescribed dose of lisinopril for past month
step_by_step: Step 2: Determine if condition worsened (may or may not have)
Step 3: Code primary condition for encounter
Step 4: Add underdosing code with character 6
Step 5: Add noncompliance code if appropriate

correct_coding.sequencing: Primary encounter reason first, underdosing secondary
correct_coding.rationale: No condition change required for underdosing code assignment (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)

incorrect_coding.code: Not coding underdosing because no symptoms
incorrect_coding.rationale: Condition change not required for underdosing codes
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Thinking symptoms are required for underdosing codes

examples.scenario: Comprehensive underdosing coding with all components

breakdown.Primary: Medical condition if worsened by underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L84)
breakdown.Secondary: Underdosing code with character 6 (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
breakdown.Additional: Noncompliance or complication code if known (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)

examples.rationale: Complete documentation includes condition, underdosing, and intent when available (Evidence: pg no: 84, L78-L86)

warnings: Never assign underdosing codes as principal or first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)
Do not require condition change documentation for underdosing codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)
best_practices: Code medical condition first if worsened by underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83-L84)
Use character "6" for all underdosing codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81)
Add noncompliance or complication codes when intent known (Evidence: pg no: 84, L84-L86)
Document underdosing even without clinical consequences (Evidence: pg no: 84, L81-L83)
common_mistakes: Using underdosing codes as principal diagnosis
Requiring symptom documentation for underdosing codes
tips: Patient-initiated discontinuation counts as underdosing (Evidence: pg no: 84, L80-L81)
Documentation of taking less medication is sufficient (Evidence: pg no: 84, L82-L83)
Always secondary, never primary diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 84, L83)
